    <!-- data preprocessed in process/process-data.js -->
    <div class="g-container  g-intro" id="">
<p class="g-body " >
	The public health debate on masks is settled, said Joseph G. Allen, director of the Healthy Buildings program at Harvard. When you wear a mask, “you protect yourself, you protect others, you prevent yourself from touching your face,” he said. And you signal that wearing a mask is the right thing to do.
</p>
<p class="g-body " >
	With coronavirus cases still rising, wearing a mask is more important than ever. In this animation, you will see just how effective a swath of fabric can be at fighting the pandemic.
</p>
</div>
<div class="sticky-label">
	
		<div class="sticky-label__wrapper sticky-label__cotton hidden">
			<p>Magnified view of the fibers of a cotton mask</p>
		</div>
	
		<div class="sticky-label__wrapper sticky-label__n95 hidden">
			<p>Magnified view of the fibers of an N95 respirator</p>
		</div>
	
</div><div class="g-imr-view" data-animation-speed="50">
  <div class="g-imr-content">
    <div class="g-item g-webgl-window g-webgl-view">
  <div class="g-webgl-window-content g-webgl-view-content">
    <div class="g-slide-text-name"></div>
  	<div class='g-slide-container'>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:2%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Masks come in many styles and materials, but they generally work in the same way. Layers of fibers capture large respiratory droplets and smaller airborne particles known as aerosols that can carry the coronavirus.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="0"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:4%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                This process is known as filtration, and a material’s ability to trap particles is called filtration efficiency.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="1"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:8%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Tightly woven cotton outperforms most common fabrics. A nonwoven material like that of an N95 respirator is most effective.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="2"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:11%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Let’s take a closer look at how filtration works at the microscopic level.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="3"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:15%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Here is how the fibers of a cotton mask compare with aerosol particles of different sizes. The coronavirus is about the size of the smallest particles, but it usually travels inside the larger ones.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="4"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:18%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                The fibers present a dense forest that the particles must navigate as they move with the air stream. The laws of physics influence how the particles interact with the fibers and how well the mask can capture them.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="5"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:23%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Larger particles are easier to trap. They slam straight into the fibers and get stuck when the air stream brings them within touching distance, or when their momentum causes them to veer off course.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="6"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:30%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                The smallest particles are bounced around by air molecules in a random zig-zag pattern, increasing the time they spend in the fiber forest and their chances of getting captured.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="7"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:35%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Medium-size particles are the hardest to filter. They evade capture because they follow the air flow, twisting and turning around the fibers.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="8"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:37.5%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Here are the fibers of an N95 respirator. They are made of synthetic material, vary in size and are arranged randomly.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="9"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:39.5%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                And they have an extra feature: an electrostatic charge that attracts and captures particles of all sizes.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="10"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:43%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Where most masks fall short, N95s excel. Their material can filter at least 95 percent of the elusive medium particles and even more of the large and small ones.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="11"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:46%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Fibers are not the only factor in filtration. Masks of all kinds vary in filtration efficiency based on their shape and fit.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="12"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:48.5%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Loose-fitting masks or those pressed against facial hair allow aerosols to leak.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="13"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:53%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                A good mask will have a large surface area, a tight fit around the edges, and a shape that leaves space around your nostrils and mouth.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="14"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:57.99999999999999%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                This creates a larger breathing zone to catch the particles and increases the chance they will encounter a fiber.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="15"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:63%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Some masks have valves that make it easier to exhale, but without filters, these valves do not trap the aerosols you breathe out, so they do little to protect others.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="16"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:66%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                A well-fitting N95 is the gold standard, but don’t worry if you can’t get your hands on one. When everyone wears a mask, the combined filtration efficiency increases.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="17"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:70%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Let’s say the mask you’re wearing filters half of the particles you exhale.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="18"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:74%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                The particles that escape disperse through the air and are further diluted.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="19"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:78%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                The particles that eventually reach someone else’s mask get filtered again, reducing the number that get through.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="20"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:81%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                “It’s become clear that cloth masks, even though they’re not as effective as the N95s, are still effective at reducing transmission,” said Linsey Marr, an aerosol expert at Virginia Tech. “Even if you’re not achieving that 95 percent reduction, something is better than nothing.”

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="21"></div>
  			</div>
      

        
      	<div class='g-slide g-webgl-slide' style="top:84%">
           <div class="g-slide-text">
             <div class="g-slide-text-annotation-wrap">
               <div class="g-slide-text-annotation ">
                

                Good ventilation and social distancing further reduce the risk of transmission. And if everyone wears a mask and keeps their distance, the collective benefit goes up.

                </div>
             </div>
           </div>
           <div class="g-slide-hotspot" data-index="22"></div>
  			</div>
      
  	</div>
  </div>
</div>

  </div>

  

</div>

all coronavirus deaths in the United States have <a oembed.title: Masks Work. Really. We’ll Show You How (Published 2020)
oembed.summary: A visual journey through the microscopic world of the coronavirus shows how masks provide an important defense against transmission.
oembed.author_name: By Or Fleisher, Gabriel Gianordoli, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Karthik Patanjali, Miles Peyton and Bedel Saget
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2Finteractive%2F2020%2F10%2F30%2Fscience%2Fwear-mask-covid-particles-ul.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="Masks Work. Really. We’ll Show You How" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>

readabilityObject.title: Masks Work. Really. We’ll Show You How
readabilityObject.content:
The public health debate on masks is settled, said Joseph G. Allen, director of the Healthy Buildings program at Harvard. When you wear a mask, “you protect yourself, you protect others, you prevent yourself from touching your face,” he said. And you signal that wearing a mask is the right thing to do.

With coronavirus cases still rising, wearing a mask is more important than ever. In this animation, you will see just how effective a swath of fabric can be at fighting the pandemic.

Magnified view of the fibers of a cotton mask

Magnified view of the fibers of an N95 respirator

Masks come in many styles and materials, but they generally work in the same way. Layers of fibers capture large respiratory droplets and smaller airborne particles known as aerosols that can carry the coronavirus.

This process is known as filtration, and a material’s ability to trap particles is called filtration efficiency.

Tightly woven cotton outperforms most common fabrics. A nonwoven material like that of an N95 respirator is most effective.

Let’s take a closer look at how filtration works at the microscopic level.

Here is how the fibers of a cotton mask compare with aerosol particles of different sizes. The coronavirus is about the size of the smallest particles, but it usually travels inside the larger ones.

The fibers present a dense forest that the particles must navigate as they move with the air stream. The laws of physics influence how the particles interact with the fibers and how well the mask can capture them.

Larger particles are easier to trap. They slam straight into the fibers and get stuck when the air stream brings them within touching distance, or when their momentum causes them to veer off course.

The smallest particles are bounced around by air molecules in a random zig-zag pattern, increasing the time they spend in the fiber forest and their chances of getting captured.

Medium-size particles are the hardest to filter. They evade capture because they follow the air flow, twisting and turning around the fibers.

Here are the fibers of an N95 respirator. They are made of synthetic material, vary in size and are arranged randomly.

And they have an extra feature: an electrostatic charge that attracts and captures particles of all sizes.

Where most masks fall short, N95s excel. Their material can filter at least 95 percent of the elusive medium particles and even more of the large and small ones.

Fibers are not the only factor in filtration. Masks of all kinds vary in filtration efficiency based on their shape and fit.

Loose-fitting masks or those pressed against facial hair allow aerosols to leak.

A good mask will have a large surface area, a tight fit around the edges, and a shape that leaves space around your nostrils and mouth.

This creates a larger breathing zone to catch the particles and increases the chance they will encounter a fiber.

Some masks have valves that make it easier to exhale, but without filters, these valves do not trap the aerosols you breathe out, so they do little to protect others.

A well-fitting N95 is the gold standard, but don’t worry if you can’t get your hands on one. When everyone wears a mask, the combined filtration efficiency increases.

Let’s say the mask you’re wearing filters half of the particles you exhale.

The particles that escape disperse through the air and are further diluted.

The particles that eventually reach someone else’s mask get filtered again, reducing the number that get through.

“It’s become clear that cloth masks, even though they’re not as effective as the N95s, are still effective at reducing transmission,” said Linsey Marr, an aerosol expert at Virginia Tech. “Even if you’re not achieving that 95 percent reduction, something is better than nothing.”

Good ventilation and social distancing further reduce the risk of transmission. And if everyone wears a mask and keeps their distance, the collective benefit goes up.
